learning_outcomes.description: Obtain a relevant and accurate history for an individual horse or a group of horses through effective communication with owners in various contexts
Describe the underlying pathophysiology of common equine diseases encountered in practice to a varied audience
Identify and correctly interpret clinical signs of common equine diseases encountered in practice
Develop a relevant problem list using information derived from the history, general assessment and physical examination of the horse
Select and justify the appropriate diagnostic procedures needed to further assess common presenting complaints in horses
Correctly interpret the results of diagnostic tests used in the investigation of common equine diseases and integrate those results in case management
Propose and communicate rational medical and surgical treatment and management of common equine diseases
Identify horses with diseases requiring referral to a specialist for further investigation and/or treatment
Possess a knowledge of the ethical standards expected of veterinarians and accept their professional responsibility to assess their own ethics and standards of conduct

Refer to VETS4022 Blackboard for specific details for each quiz.
assessments.task_description:
Quizzes are available on the Blackboard page for VETS4022.

Online quizzes based upon class content (lectures, practical sessions and tutorials). Each quiz is a timed, 30-minute quiz with 10 multiple choice questions, each quiz is worth 2.5%. The topic of each quiz will be detailed on Blackboard. The due dates will be different for each quiz and detailed instructions and due dates will be posted on BlackBoard (expect 4 quizzes per semester).

The specific due dates and tested materials will be different for each quiz and detailed instructions will be posted on Blackboard. The quizzes will be announced on Blackboard.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
Short answer (60% of marks will be short answer/written format) and multiple choice (40% of marks will be MCQ) question examination covering lectures, tutorials and practical sessions from Semester 1. The questions include both basic knowledge and problem-based questions. Some questions may include images or results from diagnostic tests.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Anaesthesia and analgesia Lectures

Fundamental principles of anaesthesia in horses. Premedication, induction, maintenance and recovery procedures. Common complication and how to prevent them. 

Sub-activity: Anaesthesia and analgesia

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05, L06, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Anaesthesia and analgesia Lectures Fundamental principles of anaesthesia in horses. Premedication, induction, maintenance and recovery procedures. Common complication and how to prevent them. Sub-activity: Anaesthesia and analgesia

learning_activities.topic:
Equine lameness and orthopaedic surgery

A thorough approach to equine lameness including foot lameness, fractures, joint disorders, tendon and ligament disorders and treatments options for lameness.

Sub-activity: Equine lameness and orthopaedic surgery

Learning outcomes: L01, L05, L06, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: Equine lameness and orthopaedic surgery A thorough approach to equine lameness including foot lameness, fractures, joint disorders, tendon and ligament disorders and treatments options for lameness. Sub-activity: Equine lameness and orthopaedic surgery

Overview of cardiac diseases in horses particularly as it relates to athletic performance. Diagnosis, prognosis and treatment of common cardiac abnormalities.

learning_activities.topic:
Ophthalmology

Principles involved in the examination, medical treatment of various eye conditions, anaesthesia of eye and eyelid conditions including (anaesthesia - the use of various nerve blocks, general anaesthesia) placement of eye treatment tubes.

Sub-activity: Ophthalmology

Learning outcomes: L01
learning_activities.topic_description: Ophthalmology Principles involved in the examination, medical treatment of various eye conditions, anaesthesia of eye and eyelid conditions including (anaesthesia - the use of various nerve blocks, general anaesthesia) placement of eye treatment tubes. Sub-activity: Ophthalmology

learning_activities.topic:
Equine clinical skills

Students will perform diagnostic procedures common in equine practice including nerve blocks, dental floating, nasogastric intubation and ocular examination. All the procedures will be performed on live animals.

Sub-activity: Equine clinical skills

Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Equine clinical skills Students will perform diagnostic procedures common in equine practice including nerve blocks, dental floating, nasogastric intubation and ocular examination. All the procedures will be performed on live animals. Sub-activity: Equine clinical skills

learning_activities.topic:
Case and client management in practice

Case-based application of the knowledge acquired in the course with a focus on the different types of equine practice.
In client communication workshops, students will work in small groups to conduct consultations with simulated clients (actors), give and receive feedback, and reflect on their own performance. This workshop will extend on theory covered in VET4022 and allows students to practice client discussions focussed on a common condition, treatment options, costs and prognosis. As such, the workshops provide a highly contextualised opportunity to further integrate and apply knowledge gained from lectures in a practical and applied setting. Students will receive 360 degree real-time multi-source feedback within the context of the workshop, which will mostly likely be conducted via ZOOM in 2021. Feedback will be related to both the communication aspects of the interaction and also the technical/ clinical content.

Sub-activity: Case and client management in practice

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L07, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Case and client management in practice Case-based application of the knowledge acquired in the course with a focus on the different types of equine practice. This workshop will extend on theory covered in VET4022 and allows students to practice client discussions focussed on a common condition, treatment options, costs and prognosis. As such, the workshops provide a highly contextualised opportunity to further integrate and apply knowledge gained from lectures in a practical and applied setting. Students will receive 360 degree real-time multi-source feedback within the context of the workshop, which will mostly likely be conducted via ZOOM in 2021.
